awd_titl_txt: NSF INCLUDES:  Early Engagement in Research: key to STEM retention
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a two-year "Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science" (INCLUDES) Design and Development Launch Pilot targeting high school students in the Hudson Valley, including the New York Metropolitan Area. It will support a network of institutional partners that are committed to providing internship and mentoring opportunities to youths interested in authentic research projects. The proposed work will build on a current research immersion program--the Secondary School Field Research Program (SSFRP) at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. SSFRP serves high school students, mainly from underrepresented and underserved communities, who work with college students, science teachers, and researchers around a specific science problem. Over the past decade, the program has had demonstrable impact, including attendance to college, and students' selection of STEM majors. Tracking data indicates that retention rates of its alumni in four-year colleges are well above the norm, and a significant fraction of early participants are now in graduate programs in science or engineering. The program has surpassed all expectations in its effectiveness at engaging underserved populations in science and promoting entry into college, recruitment into STEM majors, and retention through undergraduate and into graduate studies. Hence, the project's overall goal will be to extend and adapt the research-immersive summer internship model through an alliance with peer research institutions, school districts and networks, public land and resource management agencies, private funding agencies, informal educational institutions, and experts in pedagogical modeling, metrics, and evaluation. Focused on earth and environmental sciences, the summer and year-round mentoring model will allow high school students to work in research teams led by college students and teachers under the direction of research scientists. The mentoring model will be multilayered, with peer, near-peer, and researcher-student relationships interweaving throughout the learning process. 

The project has formulated a set of testable explanatory hypotheses: (1) Beyond specific subject knowledge, success rests on increased student engagement in a community of practice, with near-peer mentors, teachers, and scientists in the context of scientific research; (2) The intensity of engagement also shifts the students' vision of their future to include higher education, and specifically to imagine and move toward a STEM career; and (3) Early engagement, before students attend college, is critical because high school is where students form patterns of engagement and capacities related to science learning. Thus, the immediate goal of the two-year plan will be to create approximately 11 research internship programs focused on earth and environmental sciences, and to build the networks for growth through engagement with a wider community of educational partners. The main focus of this approach will be removing barriers between high school students and STEM organizations, and adapting the current mentoring model at Columbia University to the specific cultures of other research groups and internship programs throughout the lower Hudson Valley. The team has already assembled a diverse set of partners committed to broadening participation in STEM using a collective impact approach to early engagement in project-based learning. Research partners will provide the mentors, research projects, and laboratory facilities. The educational network partners will provide access for students, particularly those from under-resourced communities to participate, as well as participation opportunities for interested teachers. Informal learning organizations will provide access to field and research sites, along with research dissemination opportunities. In Year 1, the project will conduct a series of development workshops for partners already in place and foster the formation of new partnership clusters according to shared interest, complementary resources and geographic proximity. The workshops will provide a forum for partners to learn about each other's visions, values, challenges, and existing structures, while working through theoretical and practical issues related to STEM engagement for young investigators. In Year 2, the project will target the implementation of the internship programs at various sites according to the agreed-upon goals, program model, research projects, recruitment and retention strategy, staff training, data collection, and evaluation plans. An external evaluator will address both the formative and summative evaluation of the effort directed toward examining the three project?s hypotheses concerning the educational impacts of scientific research on student engagement, extent of the immersion, and overall effectiveness of the programs.

por.por_cntn:
Females, African-Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans and the rural poor have long been under-represented in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields. Through this project we strove to attract students from under-represented demographic groups, and support their development, through a series of regionally-based summer research programs rooted in local field sites and communities, and in collaboration with local non-profit groups. The project engaged undergraduate students in STEM majors from the same background as its high school participants, so there was a layered mentoring structure, including peers, near-peers, and professional scientists and educators. The program was modeled on an existing Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory program and developed with the Collective Impact Model.

We worked with over two-dozen organizations and academic institutions to develop six regional clusters in a shared structure that included layered mentoring, relevant community-focused team-oriented science research, a focus on students? personal development alongside their research, and was evaluated through using shared assessment instruments. The partners in this project worked together to provide meaningful opportunities for high school students to conduct field based geoscience research projects operated by colleges and universities in their communities. Recruitment targeted traditionally excluded populations, and was not filtered on metrics of academic achievement.

Differences in size, capacity, stage of development, and objectives between organizations and institutions presented a set of challenges, but we found that the commitment to the overarching project goal was strong enough to overcome the impediments. Since hands-on, participatory, experiential learning was central to our approach, the COVID pandemic presented a serious challenge, which we feared might even mean an end to programming, especially for our struggling non-profit partners. Instead we learned about the depths of our partners? commitment and resilience, as they mounted effective online programs.  2021 provided an entirely new challenge with constantly shifting requirements in place that effected different groups inequitably. Once again we found that our partners were committed to continuing the work and willing to devote considerable time and resources in what continued to be a stressed financial environment in order to make sure that the program continued in an exciting and meaningful format for the students. This speaks to the recognized value of the program to each organization participating in this network. The work being done has a recognized value throughout their organizational structure, and has expanded their capacity changing the way that many have traditionally operated.

Through their work in this project the high school students now see themselves as scientists, and have enhanced their confidence in both 'doing' science and in communicating about science. The student assessments demonstrated that most participating students cited an intention to remain in the sciences after their involvement with the program. This will enhance diversity in our fields and build inclusiveness in the broader scientific community.

Participation in the program has reinforced the science self-image of the undergraduate mentors and provided them an opportunity to be employed in science early in their careers. This may be just a small step in their longer careers, but providing a critical first job in the sciences is an important landmark in offering leverage for the next job.

Additionally, our scientists have expanded their communication skills and especially noted improving the listening side of communication, deepening the ?double discovery? aspect of the program. Scientists report having developed their mentorship skills through working with the extremely diverse population, as well as working and communicating with younger students entering into science research projects.

Reflections on Collective Impact

In our opinion Collective Impact is best achieved through co-development. However, we learned early in our meetings that co-development is a slow process and requires a significant amount of give and take that is difficult for some groups to manage. Not every organization has the capacity to participate equitably in a process that can take years to mature, and organizational resources affect the ability of some groups to participate in a co-development design. Small non-profits, while often more nimble in their ability to adjust to a new design, also may lack the resources to participate in projects whose principal benefits are years in the future. On the flip side, larger academic institutions can find it more difficult to shift course and accommodate a change in plans. Although these are all important considerations, there is an incredible strength in Collective Impact that is not attainable in most other structures. We felt that we achieved a large amount of program success, and witnessed the resilience of the program through a series of significant challenges the last two years. The network that developed through the collective nature of the program was a significant strength that outweighed any of the challenges. Our world increasingly focuses on collaborative work and more and more valuies convergece knoweldge, ensuring collective impact will continue to be a critical design tool.
